Claim: The Abbasid Caliphate\'s most celebrated work, though not the Caliphate itself, was cut short by North Asians.
Gold_evidence: The Abbasid historical period lasting to the Mongol conquest of Baghdad in 1258 CE is considered the Islamic Golden Age. In 1261, following the devastation of Baghdad by the Mongols, the Mamluk rulers of Egypt re-established the Abbasid caliphate in Cairo.

Claim: The german novel, The Magic Mountain, was put on hold during the beginning of World War I as the author reexamined his worldview.
Gold_evidence: The outbreak of World War I interrupted his work on the book. Given this, Mann felt compelled to radically revise and expand the pre-war text before completing it in 1924.

Claim: The film was shot in many locations including Washington, Ohio, and Pennsylvania.
Gold_evidence: Also including, the town\'s bowling alley is the Bowladrome Lanes, located at 56 State Street, Struthers, Ohio. Weirton, West Virginia, for mill and trailer shots. Steubenville, Ohio, for some mill and neighborhood shots.

Claim: The Magic Mountain is a book about a man attempting to find a mountain upon which grows a flower that will heal his wife.
Gold_evidence: The newer work reflected his experiences and impressions during a period when his wife, who was suffering from a lung complaint, resided at Dr. Friedrich Jessen\'s Waldsanatorium in Davos, Switzerland for several months. In the opening chapter, Castorp leaves his familiar life and obligations, in what he later learns to call \"the flatlands\", to visit the rarefied mountain air and introspective small world of the sanatorium.

Claim: The giant animal with a regal title in that famous tale actually climbed the Chrystler building which was much taller at the time.
Gold_evidence: A year later, the film King Kong depicted Kong, a large stop motion ape that climbs the Empire State Building, bringing the building into the popular imagination. The movie, which depicted a large stop motion ape named Kong climbing the Empire State Building, made the still-new building into a cinematic icon.

Claim: Thelonious Monk is a British musician.
Gold_evidence: Thelonious Sphere Monk (, October 10, 1917 – February 17, 1982) was an American jazz pianist and composer. Thelonious Sphere Monk was born two years after his sister Marion on October 10, 1917, in Rocky Mount, North Carolina, and was the son of Thelonious and Barbara Monk.

Claim: The Erie Canal has taken the same route since its creation.
Gold_evidence: The First Enlargement was completed in 1862, with further minor enlargements in later decades. The Genesee Valley Canal was later abandoned and became the route of the Genesee Valley Canal Railroad.

Claim: The Pacific War was multi-pronged and was fought on land and sea for dominance.
Gold_evidence: After the Battle of Angamos, once Chile achieved naval supremacy, the government had to decide where to strike. Chilean warships also had to impose a naval blockade of Peruvian ports and end the smuggling of arms from Panama into Peru via the Pacific.

Claim: Henry I got married and took the throne in 1100.
Gold_evidence: On 11 November 1100 Henry married Matilda, the daughter of Malcolm III of Scotland. Present at the place where his brother William died in a hunting accident in 1100, Henry seized the English throne, promising at his coronation to correct many of William\'s less popular policies.

Claim: Before \"True Blood\" began production, HBO and PepsiCo partnered to create a drink based on the one the vampires drink on the show.
Gold_evidence: In the same month, HBO.com began selling Tru:Blood, a beverage branded to resemble the fictional synthetic blood that appears in the show. The beverage is a carbonated blood orange-flavored drink, developed and manufactured by Omni Consumer Products, a company that specializes in defictionalizing brands from television and movies, and FMCG Manufacturing Company, a specialist manufacturer of licensed entertainment products.

Claim: British rule was a positive event and aided in equal rights for Uganda.
Gold_evidence: This was evidenced in part by hostilities between the British colonial authorities and Buganda prior to independence. There are many areas which continue to attract concern when it comes to human rights in Uganda.

Claim: Viral infections that affect plants are generally not controlled.
Gold_evidence: Severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) and Middle East respiratory syndrome (MERS)  are caused by new types of coronaviruses. When control of plant virus infections is considered economical, for perennial fruits, for example, efforts are concentrated on killing the vectors and removing alternate hosts such as weeds.

Claim: Peer Gynt is the builder of a little house.
Gold_evidence: As an outlaw, Peer struggles to build his own cottage in the hills. the cabin Peer built is close at hand, but he dares not enter.

Claim: Pyrrhus\'s reign came to an end when he lost his life in Beneventum.
Gold_evidence: The Epirote assault on Sparta was thwarted, however, and Pyrrhus was killed during a street battle at Argos. After the inconclusive Battle of Beneventum in 275 BC, Pyrrhus decided to end his campaign in Italy and return to Epirus which resulted in the loss of essentially all the gains he had made in Italy.

Claim: Monaco is a city-state.
Gold_evidence: The state consists of only one municipality (commune), the Municipality of Monaco. There is no geographical distinction between the State and City of Monaco, although responsibilities of the government (state-level) and of the municipality (city-level) are different.

Claim: The Buckingham Palace used to stink due to poor ventilation.
Gold_evidence: Ventilation was so bad that the interior smelled, and when it was decided to install gas lamps, there was a serious worry about the build-up of gas on the lower floors. There are 775 rooms, including 188 staff bedrooms, 92 offices, 78 bathrooms, 52 principal bedrooms, and 19 state rooms.

Claim: No events can be held at the Pantheon of Rome.
Gold_evidence: The Pantheon is in use as a Catholic church. Weddings are also held there from time to time.

Claim: The prison blocks in Alcatraz were named after famous cities in the United States.
Gold_evidence: Alcatraz cellhouse had a corridor naming system named after major American streets and landmarks. Prison corridors were named after major U.S. streets such as Broadway and Michigan Avenue.

Claim: The wedding in the movie The Deer Hunter had a real-life Presbyterian minister perform the rite, even though the church was Catholic.
Gold_evidence: St. Theodosius\' Father Stephen Kopestonsky was cast as the priest at the wedding. The wedding scenes were filmed at the historic St. Theodosius Russian Orthodox Cathedral in the Tremont neighborhood of Cleveland, Ohio.

Claim: President John Quincy Adams birthplace has been changed to his middle name as well as many areas open to the public in the United States speaking well of the statesman and diplomat.
Gold_evidence: Adams\'s middle name of Quincy has been used by several locations in the United States, including the town of Quincy, Illinois. John Quincy Adams was born on July 11, 1767, to John and Abigail Adams (née Smith) in a part of Braintree, Massachusetts that is now Quincy.

Claim: Tony Gwynn played for the same NL team his whole MLB career.
Gold_evidence: The left-handed hitting Gwynn won eight batting titles in his career, tied for the most in National League (NL) history. Anthony Keith Gwynn Sr. (May 9, 1960 – June 16, 2014), nicknamed \"Mr. Padre\", was an American professional baseball right fielder, who played 20 seasons (1982–2001) in Major League Baseball (MLB) for the San Diego Padres.

Claim: Mansfield Park\'s reviews were very delayed on this book.
Gold_evidence: The novel did not receive any public reviews until 1821. Mansfield Park is the third published novel by Jane Austen, first published in 1814 by Thomas Egerton.

Claim: McCartney\'s now wife is much older than him.
Gold_evidence: Shevell is about 18 years younger than McCartney. McCartney married New Yorker Nancy Shevell in a civil ceremony at Marylebone Town Hall, London, on 9 October 2011.

Claim: Penn\'s older brother, Michael, won two Academy awards while Sean won three Academy awards between 1995 and 2008.
Gold_evidence: His older brother is musician Michael Penn. Penn has appeared in more than 50 films and won many awards during his career as an actor and director.

Claim: The film Captain America: Civil War was the least successful film in the Marvel Cinematic Universe.
Gold_evidence: For IMAX in its second weekend, Captain America: Civil War earned $31 million, a new record for a day-and-date opening for a Marvel film. Two weeks ahead of its release, Fandango announced that the film outsold all previous Marvel Cinematic Universe films at the same point in the sales cycle, and by its opening week, had reached the highest advance sales for a superhero film, representing 90% of the site\'s weekend ticket sales.

Claim: The UN was instrumental in ending Apartheid.
Gold_evidence: Illustrating that over a long period of time, the United Nations was working towards isolating the state of South Africa, by putting pressure on the Apartheid regime. After much debate, by the late-1980s, the United States, the United Kingdom, and 23 other nations had passed laws placing various trade sanctions on South Africa.

Claim: Lange is a dedicated Catholic.
Gold_evidence: I\'ve never been a religious person. she does not follow any set religion, she periodically practices Buddhism.

Claim: There is no troubling string of self-terminations carried out by Foxconn\'s well-treated workers.
Gold_evidence: In reaction to a spate of worker suicides in which 14 people died in 2010, Foxconn installed suicide-prevention netting at the base of buildings in some facilities and promised to offer substantially higher wages at its Shenzhen production bases. In 2012 and into 2013, three young Foxconn employees were reported to have died by jumping off buildings.

Claim: The British won the Battles of Saratoga.
Gold_evidence: On October 17, Burgoyne surrendered his army to Gates. The Battles of Saratoga (September 19 and October 7, 1777) marked the climax of the Saratoga campaign, giving a decisive victory to the Americans over the British in the American Revolutionary War.

Claim: Bryan Adams became the ultimate vegan when he desired to shout about his vegan diet and moral superiority so hard that doing so got him called racist.
Gold_evidence: , I just wanted to have a rant about the horrible animal cruelty in these wet-markets being the possible source of the virus, and promote veganism. Even though Adams did not single out any particular race in his remarks, online response was immediate and \"Bryan Adams racist\" began trending on social media.

Claim: Satchel Paige\'s career lasted for eighteen years, playing until 1965.
Gold_evidence: He played his last professional game on June 21, 1966, for the Peninsula Grays of the Carolina League. On town tours across the United States, Paige would sometimes have his infielders sit down behind him and then routinely strike out the side.

Claim: Princess Diana advocated proximity anti-personnel explosives as a way to keep British soldiers safe and maintain minimal casualties for combat participants and civilians.
Gold_evidence: In June 1997, she gave a speech at a landmines conference held at the Royal Geographical Society, and travelled to Washington, D.C. to help promote the American Red Cross landmines campaign. Her work on the landmines issue has been described as influential in the signing of the Ottawa Treaty, which created an international ban on the use of anti-personnel landmines.

Claim: The colosseum never inspired other structures.
Gold_evidence: The Los Angeles Memorial Coliseum entrance was inspired by the Colosseum. The Palazzo della Civilta Italiana was very closely modelled on the Colosseum.

Claim: Era Records went out of business because of The Beach Boys\' song, \"Surfin.\'\"
Gold_evidence: It was so successful that the number of unpaid orders for the single bankrupted Candix. \"Surfin\'\" was a regional success for the West Coast, and reached number 75 on the national Billboard Hot 100 chart.

Claim: Xylem is derived from the Greek word, meaning plant, while xylem cells are the elements that transport oxygen, requiring them to be alive.
Gold_evidence: The most distinctive xylem cells are the long tracheary elements that transport water. By 1891, the Polish-German botanist Eduard Strasburger had shown that the transport of water in plants did not require the xylem cells to be alive.

Claim: Unlike most action films, Transformers: Dark of the Moon, didn\'t have any on-set accidents during filming.
Gold_evidence: Due to a failed weld, a steel cable snapped from a car being towed and hit the extra\'s car, damaging her skull. The injury has left her permanently brain-damaged, paralyzed on her left side and her left eye stitched shut.

Claim: Xylem relies on pressure to feed a plant.
Gold_evidence: Xylem transport is driven by a combination of transpirational pull from above and root pressure from below, which makes the interpretation of measurements more complicated. Until recently, the differential pressure (suction) of transpirational pull could only be measured indirectly, by applying external pressure with a pressure bomb to counteract it.

Claim: Richard Burton was rasied by his older sister starting around the age of two.
Gold_evidence: Richard was barely two years old when his mother died on 31 October, six days after the birth of Graham, the family\'s thirteenth child. Richard remained forever grateful and loving to Cis throughout his life, later going on to say: \"When my mother died she, my sister, had become my mother, and more mother to me than any mother could ever have been ... I was immensely proud of her ... she felt all tragedies except her own\".

Claim: Victoria became a Queen at only 18 years old.
Gold_evidence: Victoria turned 18 on 24 May 1837, and a regency was avoided. Less than a month later, on 20 June 1837, William IV died at the age of 71, and Victoria became Queen of the United Kingdom.

Claim: Leonhard Euler was an agnostic.
Gold_evidence: These works show that Euler was a devout Christian who believed the Bible to be inspired; the Rettung was primarily an argument for the divine inspiration of scripture. Much of what is known of Euler\'s religious beliefs can be deduced from his Letters to a German Princess and an earlier work, Rettung der Göttlichen Offenbahrung Gegen die Einwürfe der Freygeister (Defense of the Divine Revelation against the Objections of the Freethinkers).

Claim: Anton Bruckner loved Operatic performances for their deep and involved stories.
Gold_evidence: Although he attended performances of Wagner\'s operas, he was much more interested in the music than the plot. After seeing Wagner\'s Götterdämmerung, he asked: \"Tell me, why did they burn the woman at the end?\" Nor did Bruckner ever write an oratorio.

Claim: Hector Berlioz\'s second wife was a lady he had an affair with while he was married to the first.
Gold_evidence: During the year Berlioz completed the composition of L\'Enfance du Christ, worked on his book of memoirs, and married Marie Recio, which, he explained to his son, Her suspicion about Recio was well founded: the latter became Berlioz\'s mistress in 1841 and accompanied him on his German tour.

Claim: Battle of Gettysburg is referred to as the inflection point of the American Civil War.
Gold_evidence: The battle involved the largest number of casualties of the entire war and is often described as the war\'s turning point. Gettysburg was a landmark battle, the largest of the war and it would not be surpassed.

Claim: Some brands advertise their brand by not putting a brand on their particular brand of product, thus relying on people\'s pre-existing knowledge of their brand to aid the advertising of their brand, rather than the brand\'s brand.
Gold_evidence: \"No brand\" branding may be construed as a type of branding as the product is made conspicuous through the absence of a brand name. This no-brand strategy means that little is spent on advertisement or classical marketing and Muji\'s success is attributed to the word-of-mouth, simple shopping experience and the anti-brand movement.

Claim: The Mahabharata advocates betting, and shows the practice as non-harmful.
Gold_evidence: In the dice game, Yudhishthira loses all his wealth, then his kingdom. Shakuni, Duryodhana\'s uncle, now arranges a dice game, playing against Yudhishthira with loaded dice.

Claim: Timur  brutally occupied three countries and made preparations to battle China.
Gold_evidence: In 1400, Timur invaded Armenia and Georgia. Timur eventually planned to invade China.

Claim: Jane Addams became the 1st American woman to receive the Nobel Peace Prize.
Gold_evidence: In 1931 the award of the Nobel Peace prize earned her near-unanimous acclaim. She paved the way for women by publishing several books and co-winning the Nobel Peace Prize in 1931 with Starr.

Claim: Vidura\'s parents are Vyasa and a maid and he is one of the smartest characters in the Mahabharata.
Gold_evidence: He is born healthy and grows up to be one of the wisest characters in the Mahabharata. Vyasa fathers a third son, Vidura, by the maid.

Claim: In 2014, the company wanted to buy Samsung for $10 billion.
Gold_evidence: On September 3, 2013, Microsoft agreed to buy Nokia\'s mobile unit for $7 billion, following Amy Hood taking the role of CFO. On April 25, 2014, Microsoft acquired Nokia Devices and Services for $7.2 billion.

Claim: Charles Evans Hughes shuffled off this mortal coil in Massachusetts, and then was taken to New York to be submerged in soil.
Gold_evidence: On August 27, 1948, at the age of 86, Hughes died in what is now the Tiffany Cottage of the Wianno Club in Osterville, Massachusetts. He is interred at Woodlawn Cemetery in the Bronx, New York City.

Claim: Nikita was a great critic of Stalin.
Gold_evidence: Khrushchev greatly admired the dictator and treasured informal meetings with him and invitations to Stalin\'s dacha, while Stalin felt warm affection for his young subordinate. In 1936, as the trials proceeded, Khrushchev expressed his vehement support:  Everyone who rejoices in the successes achieved in our country, the victories of our party led by the great Stalin, will find only one word suitable for the mercenary, fascist dogs of the Trotskyite-Zinovievite gang.

Claim: Tom Cruise is an avid science denier, and should not be allowed to speak.
Gold_evidence: Cruise asserted that there is no such thing as a chemical imbalance and that psychiatry is a form of pseudoscience. They described him as a militant spokesman for Scientology, and barred any further dealings with him.

Claim: German composer Richard Strauss transformed from conservative to an advanced modern style, and his scores represent a major evolution for the movie music industry.
Gold_evidence: Strauss\'s musical style played a major role in the development of film music in the middle of the 20th century. However, Strauss\'s style began to truly develop and change when, in 1885, he met Alexander Ritter, a noted composer and violinist, and the husband of one of Richard Wagner\'s nieces.

Claim: On the Road was released in 1955.
Gold_evidence: On the Road is a 1957 novel by American writer Jack Kerouac, based on the travels of Kerouac and his friends across the United States. It was published by Viking Press in 1957.

Claim: Ariana Grande owns a drink company.
Gold_evidence: In October 2014, Grande joined the bottled water brand WAT-AAH! as an equity holder and partner.

Claim: Sun Ra was an American jazz composer who believed he was from outer space to preach to the Earthlings.
Gold_evidence: Le Sony\'r Ra (born Herman Poole Blount, May 22, 1914 – May 30, 1993), better known as Sun Ra, was an American jazz composer, bandleader, piano and synthesizer player, and poet known for his experimental music, \"cosmic\" philosophy, prolific output, and theatrical performances. Claiming to be an alien from Saturn on a mission to preach peace, he developed a mythical persona and an idiosyncratic credo that made him a pioneer of Afrofuturism.

Claim: Pierce passed away due to liver complications.
Gold_evidence: He returned to Concord that September, suffering from severe cirrhosis of the liver, knowing he would not recover. Pierce\'s health began to decline again in mid-1869; he resumed heavy drinking despite his deteriorating physical condition.

Claim: The Hurt Locker was directed by a female and won Best picture.
Gold_evidence: Although the film had not recovered its budget by the time of the ceremony, it won six Oscars, including Best Picture, Best Director for Bigelow (the first woman to win this award), and Best Original Screenplay for Boal. The Hurt Locker is a 2008 American war thriller film directed by Kathryn Bigelow and written by Mark Boal.

Claim: Joseph McCarthy falsified his military record during his Senate race against La Follette.
Gold_evidence: Because of McCarthy\'s various lies about his military heroism, his \"Tail-Gunner Joe\" nickname was sarcastically used as a term of mockery by his critics. He later falsely claimed participation in 32 aerial missions in order to qualify for a Distinguished Flying Cross and multiple awards of the Air Medal, which the Marine Corps chain of command decided to approve in 1952 because of his political influence.

Claim: The Brooklyn Bridge\'s title was changed in 1916 to avoid confusion with another bridge with a similar name.
Gold_evidence: Alternatively, the span was just referred to as the \"Brooklyn Bridge\", a name originating in a January 25, 1867, letter to the editor sent to the Brooklyn Daily Eagle. The city government passed a bill to officially name the structure the \"Brooklyn Bridge\" in January 1915.

Claim: The city is very popular for tourists for many reasons ranging from festivals to the thriving nightclub scene.
Gold_evidence: In 2008, there were 140 festivals and events in Amsterdam. On Koningsdag—that is held each year on 27 April—hundreds of thousands of people travel to Amsterdam to celebrate with the city\'s residents.

Claim: Eastwood grew up a devout Catholic because of his mother.
Gold_evidence: In 1973, Eastwood told the film critic Gene Siskel, \"No, I don\'t believe in God.\" Eastwood has said that he finds spirituality in nature (as suggested by his Western, Pale Rider, 1985), stating that \"I was born during the Depression and I was brought up with no specific church.

Claim: The band chose their name R.E.M., which stands for rapid eye movement, by picking a term at random from a child\'s book.
Gold_evidence: After considering names such as Cans of Piss, Negro Eyes, and Twisted Kites, the band settled on \"R.E.M.\", which Stipe selected at random from a dictionary. Dr. Rafael Pelayo reports that when his colleague Dr. William Dement, the sleep scientist who coined the term REM, reached out to the band, Dr. Dement was told that the band was named \"not after REM sleep\".

Claim: Bush offered assistance to Panama in the 80s to overthrow the government.
Gold_evidence: Bush objected to the annulment of the election and worried about the status of the Panama Canal with Noriega still in office. Noriega was convicted and imprisoned on racketeering and drug trafficking charges in April 1992.

Claim: Pope Julius II is often shown in art pieces with a beard even though he only wore it for a year of his time as pope and was the first pope to grow one since long ago.
Gold_evidence: Julius II is usually depicted with a beard, after his appearance in the celebrated portrait by Raphael, the artist whom he first met in 1509. However, the pope only wore his beard from 27 June 1511 to March 1512, as a sign of mourning at the loss of the city of Bologna by the Papal States.

Claim: Satchel Paige didn\'t learn his true age until he was in his 50s.
Gold_evidence: In 1959, Paige\'s mother told a reporter that he was 55 rather than 53, saying she knew this because she wrote it down in her Bible. Paige wrote in his autobiography, \"Seems like Mom\'s Bible would know, but she ain\'t ever shown me the Bible.

Claim: A neutrino is a fermion that interacts only via the weak subatomic force and gravity and gets its name from the electron and its rest mass is so large..
Gold_evidence: The neutrino is so named because it is electrically neutral and because its rest mass is so small ( -ino) that it was long thought to be zero.

Claim: The poem \"Elegy Written in a Country Churchyard\" is a poem that sets the standard to use England as a background for poetry.
Gold_evidence: Elegy Written in a Country Churchyard is a poem by Thomas Gray, completed in 1750 and first published in 1751. In choosing an \"English\" over a Classical setting, Gray provided a model for later poets wishing to describe England and the English countryside during the second half of the 18th century.
Gold_page: Elegy Written in a Country Churchyard

Claim: The Battle of Gettysburg was a full scale three day crucial battle at Little Round Top, an important hill at the extreme left of the Union line, the Wheatfield, Devil\'s Den, the Peach Orchard, Culp\'s Hill, and Cemetery Hill with the highest number of deaths of the entire war.
Gold_evidence: In the late afternoon of July 2, Lee launched a heavy assault on the Union left flank, and fierce fighting raged at Little Round Top, the Wheatfield, Devil\'s Den, and the Peach Orchard. On the Union right, Confederate demonstrations escalated into full-scale assaults on Culp\'s Hill and Cemetery Hill.

Claim: Dunes that often do not have a slipface because of wind patterns are called dome dunes and are one of the 5 types of dunes.
Gold_evidence: Dome dunes are rare and occur at the far upwind margins of sand seas. Oval or circular mounds that generally lack a slipface.

Claim: The only verified original sled prop from Citizen Kane was sold at a price of over a hundred thousand dollars.
Gold_evidence: In 1982, film director Steven Spielberg bought a \"Rosebud\" sled for $60,500; it was one of three balsa sleds used in the closing scenes and the only one that was not burned. After the Spielberg purchase, it was reported that retiree Arthur Bauer claimed to own another \"Rosebud\" sled.

Claim: Richard Nixon was an athlete growing up.
Gold_evidence: With a family history of tuberculosis, he was forbidden to play sports. Richard was twelve years old when a spot was found on his lung.

Claim: Berlioz was a physician and composer who had biographies written about his life before and after his death in France.
Gold_evidence: La Damnation de Faust, though conceived as a work for the concert hall, did not achieve success in France until it was staged as an opera long after the composer\'s death. Holoman was responsible for the publication in 1987 of the first thematic catalogue of Berlioz\'s works; two years later he published a single-volume biography of the composer.

Claim: Norma Shearer was dubbed 5 times and grew up in Canada.
Gold_evidence: Shearer was the first person to receive five Academy Award nominations for acting. Her childhood was spent in Montreal, where she was educated at Montreal High School for Girls and Westmount High School.

Claim: King Charles II had so many children by so many different women, one of his nicknames compared him to a rabbit and its breeding habits.
Gold_evidence: Charles had no legitimate children, but acknowledged a dozen by seven mistresses, including five by Barbara Villiers, Lady Castlemaine, for whom the Dukedom of Cleveland was created. As a result, in his lifetime he was often nicknamed \"Old Rowley\", the name of his favourite racehorse, notable as a stallion.

Claim: The group did not make any public appearances between Stig\'s 1986 birthday and the Sweedish premiere of Mamma Mia.
Gold_evidence: All four members made their (at the time, final) public appearance as four friends more than as ABBA in January 1986, when they recorded a video of themselves performing an acoustic version of \"Tivedshambo\" (which was the first song written by their manager Stig Anderson), for a Swedish TV show honouring Anderson on his 55th birthday. Except for a TV appearance in 1986, the foursome did not come together publicly again until they were reunited at the Swedish premiere of the Mamma Mia!

Claim: Queen Victoria was heralded throughout the island North of England for starving the Irish.
Gold_evidence: In Ireland, Victoria was labelled \"The Famine Queen\". In the next four years, over a million Irish people died and another million emigrated in what became known as the Great Famine.

Claim: Alexander II of Russia was a warmonger who led a lot of internal reforms including abolishing serfs, instating a new legal system and universal conscription.
Gold_evidence: The tsar was responsible for other reforms, including reorganizing the judicial system, setting up elected local judges, abolishing corporal punishment, promoting local self-government through the zemstvo system, imposing universal military service, ending some privileges of the nobility, and promoting university education. He has been described as looking like a German, somewhat of a pacifist, a heavy smoker and card player.

Claim: During the Punic Wars, 50k Carthaginian citizens were enslaved.
Gold_evidence: Rome demanded that if war were to be avoided, the Carthaginians must hand over all of their armaments. There were 50,000 Carthaginian prisoners, a small proportion of the pre-war population, who were sold into slavery.

Claim: Clint Eastwood, born during the beginning of the Great Depression and the fall of Wall Street, held a variety of jobs before he began his successful acting career.
Gold_evidence: Eastwood held a number of jobs, including lifeguard, paper carrier, grocery clerk, forest firefighter, and golf caddy. In 1973, Eastwood told the film critic Gene Siskel, \"No, I don\'t believe in God.\" Eastwood has said that he finds spirituality in nature (as suggested by his Western, Pale Rider, 1985), stating that \"I was born during the Depression

Claim: Onegin was only translated into English because Pushkin thought if readers did not know Russian they knew English.
Gold_evidence: There are at least a dozen published translations of Onegin in German. There are several Italian translations of Onegin.

Claim: During the Peasants\' Revolt, the rebels from Kent let the King\'s mom pass them by without hurting her.
Gold_evidence: Along their way, they encountered Lady Joan, the King\'s mother, who was travelling back to the capital to avoid being caught up in the revolt; she was mocked but otherwise left unharmed. The Kentish advance on London appears to have been coordinated with the movement of the rebels in Essex, Suffolk and Norfolk.

Claim: Stephen Hawking grew up wealthy.
Gold_evidence: His paternal great-grandmother saved the family from financial ruin by opening a school in their home. His wealthy paternal great-grandfather, from Yorkshire, over-extended himself buying farm land and then went bankrupt in the great agricultural depression during the early 20th century.

Claim: The storming of the Bastille resulted in over 80 dead revolutionaries, but all 7 prisoners were freed.
Gold_evidence: Despite a thorough search, the revolutionaries discovered only seven prisoners in the Bastille, rather fewer than had been anticipated. By now around 83 of the crowd had been killed and another 15 mortally wounded; only one of the Invalides had been killed in return.

Claim: Babe Ruth would speak German at home in his youth.
Gold_evidence: Only one of young Ruth\'s seven siblings, his younger sister Mamie, survived infancy. As a child, Ruth spoke German.

Claim: The Slipknot logo has nothing to do with devil worship.
Gold_evidence: Despite popular belief, the nonagram is not a Satanist symbol and instead represents Slipknot\'s \"battle with the fake world. and it represents a 9-point star—a symbol of unity, loyalty, friendship and remembrance.

Claim: Bon Jovi\'s 11th album was a return to their rockin\' roots.
Gold_evidence: The Circle is a return to rock n\' roll after their Nashville-influenced album, Lost Highway. On November 10, 2009, the band released their eleventh studio album, titled The Circle.

Claim: Mary Shelley came upon the idea for this story after her family decided to write ghost stories to pass the time.
Gold_evidence: \"Perhaps a corpse would be re-animated\", Mary noted, \"galvanism had given token of such things\". \" During one evening in the middle of summer, the discussions turned to the nature of the principle of life.

Claim: The play has been adapted to many different formats.

He was not prepared to dismantle apartheid, but he did try to redress South Africa\'s isolation and to revitalise the country\'s global reputation, even those with Black majority rule in Africa.

Claim: Paraguay has the warmest weather in January and is a tropical place.
Gold_evidence: January is the hottest summer month, with an average daily temperature of 28.9 degrees Celsius (84 degrees F). The overall climate is tropical to subtropical.

Claim: Collins is famous for his work with Disney.
Gold_evidence: In 2002, he received the Disney Legend award. He performed \"Two Worlds\" at that year\'s ceremony and the Disney-themed Super Bowl halftime show.

Claim: William H. Seward always hated the man that was made chief executive instead of him.
Gold_evidence: Seward had mixed feelings about the man who had blocked him from the presidency. The President is the best of us, but he needs constant and assiduous cooperation.\" According to Goodwin, \"Seward would become his most faithful ally in the cabinet ... Seward\'s mortification at not having received his party\'s nomination never fully abated, but he no longer felt compelled to belittle Lincoln to ease his pain.

Claim: The Berlin Wall helped communities to stay together.

Claim: Polymers are made up of small molecules that allow them to be highly elastic.
Gold_evidence: Since polymeric molecules are much larger and hence generally have much higher specific volumes than small molecules, the number of molecules involved in a polymeric mixture is far smaller than the number in a small molecule mixture of equal volume. Their consequently large molecular mass, relative to small molecule compounds, produces unique physical properties including toughness, high elasticity, viscoelasticity, and a tendency to form amorphous and semicrystalline structures rather than crystals.
